Indicator status - Overview

The overview table shows the assessments of the indicators from previous years, indicating whether the weather symbol for an indicator has been stable or rather volatile in the past.
The assessments presented are based on the data status as of July 2025. More recent data may be available on the online platform, as it is updated regularly.

The print version of the indicator status overview can be found here.

Indicators with several targets


For indicators with several targets that are to be achieved sequentially (for example, indicator 7.1.b), the assessments for achieving each individual target are provided. The same applies to indicators with several targets that are intended to be achieved simultaneously (for example, indicator 10.1).

Indicators with target adjustments


In addition to the currently valid targets of the Federal Government, targets that applied in the past but have since been adjusted are also shown.

All weather symbols for targets that are currently not valid are shown in grey because:
  • the target was amended in the past,
  • a nearer-term target must be achieved first, or
  • the target is only one of several that are to be achieved simultaneously.

Target
Keep the proportion of people who are materiall and socially deprived below the EU average by 2030
Status
No assessment possible
Target
Keep the proportion of persons who are materially deprived considerably below the EU-27-level by 2030
Status
Note
The Life in Europe survey (EU-SILC), which was previously conducted separately, was integrated into the microcensus as a sub-sample in 2020. Due to the change from a voluntary survey to a survey requiring information in part, combined with a new sample composition, it is not possible to compare the data of the survey year 2020 with previous years to evaluate the development of the indicators in these years (break in time series). The indicator can therefore only be assessed for the reporting years 2023 and 2024 and even these are uncertain, as only four or five data points were available for the assessment instead of the usual six.
